acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 3 from 24 hours EC50=36mg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (SIDS, 1995).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 535mg/kg representing the lower of the two testing data, 535mg/kg and 540mg/kg (SIDS (1995)).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Harmful to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although acute toxicity was Category 3 and the bio-accumulation potential was low (BCF=3(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), since there was no rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 0%(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), it was classified into Category 3.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though the substance contains nitro groups with its oxygen budget calculated at  -151. According to Bretherick (J) (5th, 1998), the kick-off temperature is 213degC, whereas the decomposition energy is 1.882kJ/g (280-380degC), which can be classified as "Explosives." Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#1661 (o-, m-, p-)) (UN Recommendation on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Insufficient data available, though classified as flammable(HSDB (2006)) and the powder or granules, when mixed with the air, may cause dust explosion (ICSC (2004)) . Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#1661(o-, m-, p-)) (UN Recommendation on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests, germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and germ cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, and positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (micronucleus tests), described in Report by the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (1994), NTP DB (Access on June, 2006) and SIDS (1995).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: No data available, though being organic compounds containing oxygen bound to the elements other than carbon and hydrogen. Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#1661 (o-, m-, p-)) (UN Recommendation on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#1661 (o-, m-, p-)) (UN Recommendation on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the indication of a potential of parturition or lactation disorder at doses inducing parental toxicity, described in Report by the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (1994).

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available (melting point: 114degC (ICSC, 2002), test temperature: 140degC).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Not classified with the kick-off temperature of 213degC (Bretherick (J) (5th, 1998)), though the substance contains nitro groups with explosive properties. Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#1661 (o-, m-, p-)) (UN Recommendation on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Some human epidemiological studies provide evidence of eye irritation potential (PATTY (4th, 1999)): "The substance is rapidly absorbed through intact skin, causing irritation of the skin, eye and mucous membranes." However, classification is not possible since the severity of the effects is not presented.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Some human epidemiological studies provide evidence of skin irritation potential (PATTY (4th, 1999)): "The substance is rapidly absorbed through intact skin, and irritates the skin, eye and mucous membranes." However, classification is not possible since the severity of the effects is not presented.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver, blood system, testis)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "Chronic exposure can cause liver damage" (HSDB (2003)), "may adversely affect the blood system, forming methemoglobin" (ICSC (J) (2001)). Also based on the evidence from animal studies including "cyanosis, methemoglobinemia, testicular atrophy and hepatocyte swelling" (Report by the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (1994)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 2.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs (blood system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "Acute exposure can cause methemoglobinemia, cyanosis" (HSDB (2003)). Also based on the evidence from animal studies including "increased methemoglobin and sulfhemoglobin levels in blood" (HSDB (2003)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 2. The priority rating for the referenced study for human effects is 2.
